bibl.title: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Philip Showalter Hench, September 17, 1950

div1.p: Lawrence Reed informs Hench that Blossom Reed has been hospitalized. He discusses Blossom's financial difficulties and offers his opinions on the subject. He writes at length about Blossom's history of mental problems.

div1.head: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Philip Showalter Hench, September 17, 1950
div1.opener:
MAJOR GENERAL WALTER L. REED
2810 THIRTY SIX PLACE
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Sept. 17th _50
My dear Dr Hench-
div1.p:
I have intended writing you
for some time, to acquaint you with Blossom's
illness, but for some accountable reason I
failed to do so.

Blossom began to show symptoms
of her old trouble shortly after Mother's death.
At first Dr Bredgers hoped he could pull her
through up at The Summit, but he finally
decided it would be far better to have her
come to the W. R Hospl

Three weeks ago today I went up
to the Summit to see Blossom to invite her
down to visit me for a while, Dr. Bredgers
thought that a change might turn the trick,
but she simply would not come, said she had
too much to do to leave at that time-

I could tell she was not herself
but could not get her to tell me what her
troubles were although I strongly suspected
that it was financial worries-

I had previously explained to her, that
now that her income was drastically cut,
she could overcome the difficulty by renting
her cottage and spending the winter with
me. This she fiercely declined to do-

The next Wednesday (2 1/2 weeks ago)
Dr. Bredgers called me by phone and said
I better get the W R Hosplto send an
ambulance, The W. R. H. sent a Dr and a
nurse along and she came down quite
willingly and she is now in the N. P. Section

Her Doctors seem to think she
is progressing satisfactorily-

This is Blossom's fifth (5)
attack in the last 9- years- In 41
she was in the W R Hospl Ward 4 (open
ward) about 3 mo. In 42 she was
in the N P. Sect of the W R Hospe and St
Elizabeth- from Oct to Feb 1. Since then
she has had two minor attacks both of
which she recovered from without being
hospitalized
MAJOR GENERAL WALTER L. REED
2810 THIRTY SIX PLACE
WASHINGTON, D. C.
This present attack appears to be less
severe than the two other occassions when
she had to be hospitalized-

Her second attack and this one
appear to be due to financial difficulties-
It has always been hard for her to face
financial difficulties she prefers to take
the line of least resistance, believing “The
Lord will provide”

While her present financial difficulty
problem is a little difficult it is by no means
hopeless- unless she simply refuses to see
that her income has been cut to the point
where she must change her mode of living-

Of course she is terribly sentimental
and has a peculiar false idea that she is enlisted
to this role I have tried to dissuade her of
many of her ideas & dreams but to no appreciable
effect- Therefore the time has come when her
Drs & I must lay the law down to her so>
Ac
R
firmly that she will (I hope) have to
realize whats what and I live accordingly

So long as I am alive she
should not have to worry but in her
present instability Im not so she sure
how she will take it-

She has in the past spoken of
selling this, that and the other- I have told
her she has nothing that has any real
value (other than her house) I'm afraid
she will bother you & Col Siler with
her ideas, thats why I have written
in such detail, so you will better
understand and not take her too seriously

I will keep you informed, from
time to time how she is doing
